image.altText: A close-up of the backs of the heads of two Aboriginal children.

items.synopsis: South Australia's Aboriginal Children's Commissioner is urging the state government to reduce the number of First Nations children entering out-of-home care, to avoid a repeat of the Stolen Generation.

title.children: SA Aboriginal children entering care predicted to reach Stolen Generation levels without change, report finds

image.altText: A greyhound in a kennel.

items.synopsis: As a former greyhound adoption worker speaks out about what she witnessed during her time in the industry, an MP releases what she described as "graphic and concerning and disturbing" photos of emaciated dogs and squalid kennels. Warning: This story contains content that may distress some readers.

title.children: Greyhound mistreatment concerns trigger release of 'concerning and disturbing' photos in parliament

image.altText: A road with trees fallen over due to strong winds.

items.synopsis: Heavy rain in Victoria brings some relief to firefighters, but residents now face the threat of flash flooding, as emergency services respond to 300 calls for help.

title.children: Victorian towns welcome downpour after bushfires, but now face flood threat

image.altText: A woman looks directly at camera.

items.synopsis: Thousands of Australians opted to do their grocery shopping online during the pandemic, but plenty are yet to return to shopping in store as they try to get the most bang for their buck amid the high cost of living.

title.children: Sarah does 90 per cent of her grocery shopping online — but she's not checking out at the big supermarkets

image.altText: A massive plume of bushfire smoke looms above the hills beyond a country suburb.

items.synopsis: More hot, dry and windy conditions are expected to challenge fire crews today, but potential danger of a different kind is causing concern elsewhere in the state.

title.children: Homes lost as fires threaten NSW coast while inland residents face flood risk

image.altText: A roll cloud over the ocean

items.synopsis: Thunderstorms and heavy rain are forecast for parts of Victoria and New South Wales, dousing fires but bringing the threat of flash flooding, as a low pressure system intensifies over the eastern states.

title.children: Dangerous wind, heavy rain, flooding forecast to hit eastern states as intense storm system deepens

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in Voice referendum

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says more than 600,000 people have voted early in the referendum. "I take great heart in that, that Australians are eager to vote 'Yes' in this referendum because they know what it's about is just two things: recognition of First Nations people in our nation's founding document and secondly about a non-binding advisory committee," he said. "That's all this is. [It's] to give advice on matters affecting Indigenous Australians, because if you do that, if you listen to people, you get better outcomes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says more than 600,000 Australians have voted

props.alt: A man wearing glasses in a suit and a tie.

children.content: Anthony Albanese spoke briefly on the Voice while he was in south Sydney this morning.
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: 'Yes' campaigners point to an 80 per cent approval rating of the Voice amongst Indigenous Australians. ABC's Carly Williams and Fran Kelly have explored where the 80 per cent statistic came from and whether it is still accurate, in the video below.

image.altText: group of indigenous men standing

items.synopsis: Since 2000, the rate of Indigenous Australians imprisoned has risen eight times that of non-Indigenous Australians. There are hopes a Voice to Parliament will help reverse that trend.

title.children: Australia has one of the highest Indigenous incarceration rates in the world. Could a Voice to Parliament change that?

image.altText: Flowers next to a tree with a police car in the background

items.synopsis: A road toll rise in parts of Australia has experts worried that we are going backwards on road safety.

title.children: There's a big misconception about mobile phones and driving, and it's putting us at risk

image.altText: Kevin McCarthy in profile

items.synopsis: For the first time in American history, members of congress have voted to dump the speaker in the House of Representatives, with Republicans turning on each other to oust Kevin McCarthy.

title.children: Insults, drama and Republicans on the brink: Why America's conservatives just tore down their leader

image.altText: Fitness coach Cass Olholm

items.synopsis: A company founded by Adelaide fitness superstar Kayla Itsines has taken a former employee to court, seeking to stop her from launching a rival fitness app.

title.children: Company founded by Kayla Itsines takes rival trainer to court over launch of fitness app

image.altText: A speed sign on the side of a country road. Its numerals have been altered with tape so that it reads "No".

items.synopsis: Speed signs altered to read "No" have been spotted in SA, sparking safety concerns and a police investigation.

title.children: Multiple speed signs defaced as early voting for the Voice gets underway

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A District Court Civil Judge has granted an application to prevent an Adelaide woman accused of murdering her parents from accessing their estate.

title.children: Woman accused of killing parents denied access to their estate

image.altText: A woman and her son sit on a bench near a tree in the sun.

items.synopsis: Nagorno-Karabakh is trapped in the eye of a swirling geopolitical storm of duelling world powers. For decades, Russia has played a role in mediating conflict around the enclave, but Azerbaijan’s move to take back the area has exposed Moscow's waning influence.

title.children: A crisis unfolding in Putin's backyard has exposed the ripple effects of his dwindling power

image.altText: A man ina full body yellow suit and protective gear lights some wild grass on fire.

items.synopsis: Human error has been blamed for an incorrect tally of the number of hazard reduction burns carried out in Queensland.

title.children: Queensland's fire chief mistakenly provided incorrect hazard reduction figure ahead of bushfire season, announces resignation

image.altText: A number of people cross an intersection in Brisbane's CBD. Behind them are office buildings.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is set to fall when trade begins after Wall Street saw sharp losses in response to stronger-than-expected jobs data in the US, stoking fears interest rates will remain higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Stronger-than-expected US jobs data stokes 'higher for longer' interest rate fears, Wall Street finishes lower, ASX to dip

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Pilots working for Network Aviation, a Qantas subsidiary that flies fly-in fly-out (FIFO) and regional community routes across Western Australia, will stop work today as part of ongoing industrial action. The pilots provide services for the QantasLink brand, which operates intra-state flights that carry mostly FIFO workers. Spokesman for the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, Chris Aikens, said pilots are seeking rates of pay that are comparable to other airlines. Earlier in the week, Qantas warned around half of today's scheduled flights would be cancelled due to the strike. Mining companies and regional businesses are expecting to be affected, and have been encouraged to make alternative arrangements. The chief operating officer at Network Aviation, Trevor Worgan, says 75% of passengers should get to their destination today — and the rest have been put up in hotels. "We've done everything we can to be proactive, so people should know the flights that they're on, and we've communicated that to them, " he said. "I'm not anticipating disruption at the airport ." You can read more about the strike below from my colleagues at ABC Pilbara below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Happening today: QantasLink pilots go on strike in WA

featuredLink.title: Miners, businesses scramble to source alternative flights as QantasLink pilot strike looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tourism experts say airfares will remain high until next year, as limited capacity keeps prices up. Seat numbers on domestic flights are at 97% of pre-COVID levels, but international flights have returned to just 76%. David Beirman from the University of Technology says heavily travelled domestic routes are back to normal, but limited capacity on regional and international routes is keeping fares high. "I don't honestly foresee airfares across the board, coming down much until about mid 2024 ," he said. You can read the full story from Catherine Hanrahan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Airfares to stay high until mid-next year as low capacity remains

featuredLink.title: Flight prices still remain high after COVID, but some tickets are much more expensive than others

children.content: Tourism experts say airfares will remain high until next year, as limited capacity keeps prices up.
Seat numbers on domestic flights are at 97% of pre-COVID levels, but international flights have returned to just 76%.
David Beirman
from the University of Technology says heavily travelled domestic routes are back to normal, but limited capacity on regional and international routes is keeping fares high.
"I don't honestly foresee airfares across the board,
coming down much until about mid 2024
," he said.
You can read the full story from
Catherine Hanrahan
below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The board of the Future Fund will be required to periodically disclose investment holdings in a bid to improve transparency. The new reporting regime will make public the amount and value of shares the sovereign wealth fund has invested in companies and the level of investment in property and other infrastructure. The requirements closely mirror those applied to superannuation funds. The Future Fund is an independently managed financial asset fund, designed to help future governments' long-term financial position for unfunded superannuation liabilities when an ageing population will put significant pressure on government finances.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Future Fund board required to disclose investment holdings to improve transparency

children.content: The board of the Future Fund will be required to
periodically disclose investment holdings
in a bid to improve transparency.
The new reporting regime will
make public the amount and value of shares the sovereign wealth fund has invested in companies
and the level of investment in property and other infrastructure.
The requirements closely mirror those applied to superannuation funds.

The Future Fund is an independently managed financial asset fund, designed to help future governments' long-term financial position for unfunded superannuation liabilities when an ageing population will put significant pressure on government finances.
